Award.AbstractNarration:
This project funded by the REU Sites Program in the Chemistry Division and the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) both at the National Science Foundation (NSF) supports a Research Experience for Undergraduates Site at South Dakota State University, led by Professor James A. Rice and colleagues. The site will support ten students during the ten week summer program that will focused on environmental and green materials chemistry and provide the students with multi-disciplinary research experiences. The goal is to provide cutting-edge research experiences, mentoring, and research-themed professional development to increase the students' preparedness to pursue graduate school or environmental/green chemistry careers. The Site will introduce students to environmental and green chemistry where they will learn about natural and industrial chemical processes that impact societal research needs. These range from understanding climate change to the fate and behavior of anthropogenic chemicals introduced into natural and biological systems, and to making new materials with a reduced reliance on harmful solvents.

The REU site will recruit students from institutions with limited research opportunities with the primary emphasis on attracting students who attend tribal colleges, public and private (predominately undergraduate) institutions in South Dakota and western Minnesota. The Site will explore a distributive concept where the students will work in different locations (the host institution, Black Hills State University and Northern State University) and communicate using Access Grid, a high definition, internet-based communication system. An expected outcome will be to integrate undergraduate research into the chemistry curricula at the predominately undergraduate partner institutions as they work to achieve degree certification by the American Chemical Society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the world's population grows, so do human impacts on the environment. The research undertaken in this REU Site is providing information that could be used to understand the atmosphere and surface environments, and how to mitigate human impact on those environments. Specific students investigated more environmentally friendly chemical reactions through the use of catalysts, renewable feedstocks, and safer solvents; advanced chemical analysis methods were developed; and environmental processes explored.

Students have organized and presented their research at statewide, regional and national conferences.

The evaluation of authentic research experiences for undergraduate science students is critical to furthering our understanding of best practices in offering such programs. Using these outcomes to enhance future REU sites will encourage students to continue in STEM disciplines and become innovators of the next generation of scientists. Student participants indicated that the most positive aspects of their REU participation were establishing a connection with their mentor and hands-on work with sophisticated scientific instrumentation. Students reported the least impactful parts of the REU experience were some of the professional development activities/seminars; two mentioned specifically were the laboratory safety and introduction to ethics in research seminars.

Administrators from the PUI (primarily undergraduate institution) participants all indicated that significant efforts are underway to either build or grow a culture of research among faculty, in hopes that such a culture will filter into their classroom activities and influence students to join their labs.  However, some faculty mentors indicated that “there is a long way to go” to affect a change among both faculty and administrators, much less students, in creating a culture of research. When administrators were asked about their individual institutions, the major barriers to incorporation of research into curricula cited were lacking of consistent funding and providing time for such activities into faculty workload.
